div.div: Growth trend noted 2000–2019; see ortho epidemiology reports and our cited paper.
TKA procedures are rising with longer life expectancy and QoL demand
PJI is devastating when it occurs (burden on patients & clinicians)
Indicative rate shared: ~5 in 100 (context: Dr. Tsai, clinical experience)
Clinical relevance (surgeon interviews)
Biofilm infection in Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) → Periprosthetic Joint Infection (PJI)
Infection around implant; biofilm on abiotic surfaces → shields bacteria from immunity & antibiotics
Leads to pain, dysfunction, revision surgeries, high cost, reduced quality of life
1) What problem are we solving?
Time- & resource-intensive, relapse risk, multi-stage revisions
Biofilm matrix (polysaccharides, proteins, eDNA) → antimicrobial tolerance & persistence
Hard to cure with current options
No single good solution currently combining: fast clearance, low invasiveness, safety, and low recurrence
2) Why does this deserve solving (now)?
Use oral or IV antibiotics to suppress infection.
Goal: control inflammation and prevent biofilm from maturing.
🧩 Limitation: systemic antibiotics have poor penetration through biofilm, which leads to frequent recurrence.
(A) Slight / early-stage infection → Antibiotic treatment (without surgery)
Remove necrotic and infected tissues.
During operation, surgeons often use diluted bleach + iodine solution to disinfect, proven effective against biofilm.
Temporarily fills and reinforces the bone cavity after removing the old joint.
Releases antibiotics locally to control infection.
Only surface antibiotics (~5 mm depth) release effectively for the first 3 days.
After ~1 week, the cement becomes a substrate for new biofilm growth.
⚠️ Limitation:
Therefore, used only as a temporary solution before implanting the new artificial joint.
Continue oral antibiotics to eliminate remaining bacteria.
1. Surgery with artificial joint replacement

Instead of removing the implant, antibiotics are continuously injected into the infected cavity,
allowing the region to “soak” in antibiotics over time.
This approach is mainly observed in some clinical cases in China.
🚨 Risk: bacteria may persist within the existing implant surface despite intensive treatment.
2. Surgery without artificial joint replacement (aggressive approach)
(B) Severe / chronic infection → Surgery required
Regardless of the approach, all patients complete an oral antibiotic course after surgery to ensure bacteria suppression.
(C) Common follow-up treatment
3) Current solutions (baseline)
(1) Degrade biofilm (matrix components incl. eDNA/protein/polysaccharide)
(2) Support antibiotics (restore planktonic susceptibility)
Engineer E. coli to deliver a 3-enzyme combination at the right spot to:
Which enzymes? How to co-express & release?
Why E. coli chassis?
How to target the implant site & ensure biosafety?
4) Our idea (at a glance)
Genetic tools, high expression, modular secretion systems, rapid iteration
Using E. coli inside body → safety, immunogenicity, endotoxicity, horizontal gene transfer
Non-pathogenic chassis; payload control (induction logic); kill-switches, auxotrophy
Confinement (e.g., localized delivery/encapsulation)
Thorough biosafety review and bench-level containment testing
5) Why E. coli? (and concerns we address)
Co-expression of 3 enzymes; coordinated secretion/release at biofilm interface
Induction scheme compatible with delivery context (no patient-unsafe inducers)
Favor local/topical application to the implant region to limit spread
Enzymes loosen/disperse biofilm → antibiotics reach & eradicate → reduce recurrence
6) HOW it works (design overview)
Plasmid(s) for 3 enzymes (balanced RBS/operons); secretion tags or controlled lysis for release
Biofilm formation & clearance (e.g., microtiter crystal-violet, CFU, microscopy)
Enzymatic activity on purified matrix components (eDNA/protein/polysaccharide surrogates)
Synergy tests: enzymes ± antibiotics; time-kill curves
Bench tests of kill-switch behavior; auxotrophy; no-growth outside defined media
7) Experiment design (concise plan)
Off-target colonization, inflammation/endotoxin, HGT, uncontrolled persistence
Non-pathogenic strain; minimal genome/payload; kill-switch; auxotrophy; localized dosing
Documentation: risk assessment, expert consultations, stepwise escalation criteria
8) Risks & biosafety (what we heard, what we do)
Orthopedic surgeons → clinical need & workflow constraints
Infectious disease → safety red flags, antibiotic pairing advice
Knowledge gap on “biofilm”
Top concern: safety → address prominently in design & comms
Public perception (survey + medical humanities)
9) Stakeholder & evidence backbone
Surgeon interviews (TKA/PJI burden); Dr. Tsai (≈5%)
Public survey results (biofilm awareness & safety concerns)
Ortho epidemiology (TKA growth & PJI relevance)
Bench protocols: biofilm assays; enzyme synergy with antibiotics
References & Notes (kept concise; detailed list on the wiki page)
10) Impact & path to translation
Biofilm infection in TKA (PJI)
